entry.title: Leetcode#133. Clone Graph
entry.content:
Problem

Given a reference of a node in aÂ connectedÂ undirected graph.

Return aÂ deep copyÂ (clone) of the graph.

Each node in the graph contains a value (int) and a list (List[Node]) of its neighbors.

Test case format:

For simplicity, each nodeâ€™s value is the same as the nodeâ€™s index (1-indexed). For example, the first node withÂ val == 1, the second node withÂ val == 2, and so on. The graph is represented in the test case using an adjacency list.

An adjacency listÂ is a collection of unorderedÂ listsÂ used to represent a finite graph. Each list describes the set of neighbors of a node in the graph.

The given node will always be the first node withÂ val = 1. You must return theÂ copy of the given nodeÂ as a reference to the cloned graph.

Example 1:

!https://assets.leetcode.com/uploads/2019/11/04/133_clone_graph_question.png

Example 2:

!https://assets.leetcode.com/uploads/2020/01/07/graph.png

Example 3:

Constraints:

  • The number of nodes in the graph is in the rangeÂ [0, 100].
  • 1 <= Node.val <= 100
  • Node.valÂ is unique for each node.
  • There are no repeated edges and no self-loops in the graph.
  • The Graph is connected and all nodes can be visited starting from the given node.

Solve

entry.title: Leetcode#205. Isomorphic Strings
entry.content:
Problem

Given two stringsÂ sÂ andÂ t,Â determine if they are isomorphic.

Two stringsÂ sÂ andÂ tÂ are isomorphic if the characters inÂ sÂ can be replaced to getÂ t.

All occurrences of a character must be replaced with another character while preserving the order of characters. No two characters may map to the same character, but a character may map to itself.

Example 1:

Input:Â s = â€œeggâ€, t = â€œaddâ€

Output:Â true

Explanation:

The stringsÂ sÂ andÂ tÂ can be made identical by:

  • MappingÂ 'e'Â toÂ 'a'.
  • MappingÂ 'g'Â toÂ 'd'.

Example 2:

Input:Â s = â€œfooâ€, t = â€œbarâ€

Output:Â false

Explanation:

The stringsÂ sÂ andÂ tÂ can not be made identical asÂ 'o'Â needs to be mapped to bothÂ 'a'Â andÂ 'r'.

Example 3:

Input:Â s = â€œpaperâ€, t = â€œtitleâ€

Output:Â true

Constraints:

  • 1 <= s.length <= 5 * 104
  • t.length == s.length
  • sÂ andÂ tÂ consist of any valid ascii character.

Solve

entry.title: Leetcode#20. Valid Parentheses
entry.content:
Problem

Given a stringÂ sÂ containing just the charactersÂ '(',Â ')',Â '{',Â '}',Â '['Â andÂ ']', determine if the input string is valid.

An input string is valid if:

  1. Open brackets must be closed by the same type of brackets.
  2. Open brackets must be closed in the correct order.
  3. Every close bracket has a corresponding open bracket of the same type.

Example 1:

Example 2:

Example 3:

Constraints:

  • 1 <= s.length <= 104
  • sÂ consists of parentheses onlyÂ '()[]{}'.

entry.title: Leetcode#1319. Number of Operations to Make Network Connected
entry.content:
Problem

There areÂ nÂ computers numbered fromÂ 0Â toÂ n - 1Â connected by ethernet cablesÂ connectionsÂ forming a network whereÂ connections[i] = [ai, bi]Â represents a connection between computersÂ aiÂ andÂ bi. Any computer can reach any other computer directly or indirectly through the network.

You are given an initial computer networkÂ connections. You can extract certain cables between two directly connected computers, and place them between any pair of disconnected computers to make them directly connected.

ReturnÂ the minimum number of times you need to do this in order to make all the computers connected. If it is not possible, returnÂ -1.

Example 1:

!https://assets.leetcode.com/uploads/2020/01/02/sample_1_1677.png

Example 2:

!https://assets.leetcode.com/uploads/2020/01/02/sample_2_1677.png

Example 3:

Constraints:

  • 1 <= n <= 105
  • 1 <= connections.length <= min(n * (n - 1) / 2, 105)
  • connections[i].length == 2
  • 0 <= ai, bi < n
  • ai != bi
  • There are no repeated connections.
  • No two computers are connected by more than one cable.

Solve

entry.title: Leetcode#450. Delete Node in a BST
entry.content:
Problem

Given a root node reference of a BST and a key, delete the node with the given key in the BST. ReturnÂ theÂ root node referenceÂ (possibly updated) of the BST.

Basically, the deletion can be divided into two stages:

  1. Search for a node to remove.
  2. If the node is found, delete the node.

entry.title: Leetcode#380. Insert Delete GetRandom O(1)
entry.content:
Problem

Implement theÂ RandomizedSetÂ class:

  • RandomizedSet()Â Initializes theÂ RandomizedSetÂ object.
  • bool insert(int val)Â Inserts an itemÂ valÂ into the set if not present. ReturnsÂ trueÂ if the item was not present,Â falseÂ otherwise.
  • bool remove(int val)Â Removes an itemÂ valÂ from the set if present. ReturnsÂ trueÂ if the item was present,Â falseÂ otherwise.
  • int getRandom()Â Returns a random element from the current set of elements (itâ€™s guaranteed that at least one element exists when this method is called). Each element must have theÂ same probabilityÂ of being returned.

You must implement the functions of the class such that each function works inÂ averageÂ O(1)Â time complexity.

Example 1:

Constraints:

  • 231 <= val <= 231 - 1
  • At mostÂ 2 *Â 105Â calls will be made toÂ insert,Â remove, andÂ getRandom.
  • There will beÂ at least oneÂ element in the data structure whenÂ getRandomÂ is called.

Solve

entry.title: Leetcode#80. Remove Duplicates from Sorted Array II
entry.content:
Problem

Given an integer arrayÂ numsÂ sorted inÂ non-decreasing order, remove some duplicatesÂ in-placeÂ such that each unique element appearsÂ at most twice. TheÂ relative orderÂ of the elements should be kept theÂ same.

Since it is impossible to change the length of the array in some languages, you must instead have the result be placed in theÂ first partÂ of the arrayÂ nums. More formally, if there areÂ kÂ elements after removing the duplicates, then the firstÂ kÂ elements ofÂ numsÂ should hold the final result. It does not matter what you leave beyond the firstÂ kÂ elements.

ReturnÂ kÂ after placing the final result in the firstÂ kÂ slots ofÂ nums.

DoÂ notÂ allocate extra space for another array. You must do this byÂ modifying the input arrayÂ in-placeÂ with O(1) extra memory.

Custom Judge:

The judge will test your solution with the following code:

If all assertions pass, then your solution will beÂ accepted.

Example 1:

Example 2:

Constraints:

  • 1 <= nums.length <= 3 * 104
  • 104 <= nums[i] <= 104
  • numsÂ is sorted inÂ non-decreasingÂ order.

Solve

Leetcode-26-Remove-Duplicates-from-Sorted-Array
